Award.AwardTitle: AF: Small: Collaborative Research: Representation-theoretic techniques for pseudorandomness and lower bounds

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Fourier analysis, where we decompose a complex function into a sum of simple oscillations, is used in virtually every form of digital technology, from JPEG compression to voice recognition. In computer science, Fourier analysis has led to new algorithms for "pseudorandom numbers," i.e., numbers with no apparent pattern, which are useful both in cryptography and in algorithms for estimating functions and confirming computational claims. Fourier analysis also plays a key role in Shor's quantum algorithm for factoring, which breaks RSA public-key cryptography, and in proofs that some problems are hard to solve with certain kinds of parallel algorithms or circuits.

Profs. Moore and Russell will use the more powerful tool of nonabelian Fourier analysis to obtain new results in these areas. In particular, they propose new ways to "derandomize" algorithms, replacing random numbers with pseudorandom ones. They will study the extent to which rich, high-dimensional structures can be embedded in low-dimensional spaces with only a small amount of distortion, and prove that certain problems require a long time even for quantum computers to solve. Finally, they will study whether some alternatives to RSA, such as the McEliece cryptosystem based on error-correcting codes, will remain secure even if and when quantum computers are built. Thus their research has important impacts on algorithms, security, and cryptography. They teach courses that train students from Physics and Computer Science to work at the boundary between these disciplines, and their outreach activities include bringing this material to high school and middle-school teachers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Randomness can be a powerful computational resource; it can be especially useful when one must, for example, break symmetries or explore an unknown environment. This project has studied ways to use mathematical objects studied in algebra and harmonic analysis to replace randomness with deterministic choices or, alternatively, reduce the amount of randomness required for a specific task--when this is possible, we say that such objects are "pseudorandom," meaning that they possess properties that are as "good" as random choices in some respects.

The project has constructed a variety of new pseudorandom tools and algorithms that apply these tools. In one case, the project used pseudorandom tools to develop a new algorithm that mobile devices in a multichannel radio environment can use to discover each other, even when they do not necessarily have access to the same channels or start looking for each other at the same time. The project has also designed algorithms to solve similar discovery problems between wireless devices that are duty-cycled so that they can only transmit during very short periods of time--in this case, the problem of discovery is challenging even when they share a single common radio channel.

The project has also developed new pseudorandom techniques for computational Fourier analysis (relevant, for example, for processing data on high-dimensional spheres), answered some fundamental questions about finite Fourier analysis, and developed new varieties of cryptographic tools that can maintain security even when the algorithms themselves are subject to attack.

The project has supported several graduate students at the University of Connecticut, three of which have gone on to positions in academia; two of these are women. The project has also supported new course development (focusing on pseudorandomness and cryptography) at the University of Connecticut.
